message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s lack of menstruation, Tanner IV breasts, and Tanner I pubic hair suggest primary amenorrhea with normal breast development but absent or non-functioning gonads. Genetic testing is necessary to diagnose the specific cause of this condition, but the best course of management for this patient is gonadectomy to prevent the development of gonadal malignancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has primary amenorrhea with Tanner IV breasts, which suggests normal breast development but absence of uterus and vagina. Genetic testing should be performed to confirm a diagnosis of Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome. Treatment for MRKH syndrome is gonadectomy to prevent malignancy in the undescended gonads and creation of a neovagina. Estrogen replacement therapy and vaginoplasty alone are not appropriate. ACTH stimulation test is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of MRKH syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s exam findings suggest Müllerian agenesis, which is a congenital condition where the uterus and upper portion of the vagina fail to develop. Gonadectomy is recommended to prevent the risk of malignancy associated with retained gonads in individuals with Müllerian agenesis. Estrogen replacement therapy and vaginoplasty may be appropriate, but a gonadectomy is necessary first. ACTH stimulation test is not indicated for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s exam shows Tanner IV breasts and minimal axillary hair, but a 5 cm blind pouch for the vagina, indicating a possible Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, which also has normal 46, XX karyotype. Gonadectomy may be necessary to prevent complications related to undetected gonadal malignancies or tumors. Estrogen replacement therapy can be helpful for symptomatic relief but does not address the underlying issue. Vaginoplasty may be considered later for cosmetic or sexual function reasons. ACTH stimulation test is not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has primary amenorrhea with normal breast development and no pubic or axillary hair, which suggests Müllerian agenesis. Gonadectomy is the correct management option in this case. Estrogen replacement therapy and vaginoplasty may be considered later for cosmetic and functional purposes, respectively. ACTH stimulation test is used to assess adrenal function and is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of Tanner IV breasts and a blind pouch vagina suggest Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome. The best next step in management is gonadectomy to remove the testes, which are the source of androgen production. Estrogen replacement therapy is not necessary since the patient already has breast development. Vaginoplasty may be considered in the future if desired, but gonadectomy is the first step. ACTH stimulation test is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the presence of Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), which means the patient’s body develops as a female but her cells are unable to respond appropriately to androgens, resulting in a male phenotype. The blind pouch vagina and Tanner IV breasts support this diagnosis. The best next step in management is gonadectomy, which is done to prevent the development of testicular cancer. Estrogen replacement therapy would not be effective and vaginoplasty is not recommended until counseling about gender identity is completed. ACTH stimulation test is not indicated for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's lack of menstruation, Tanner IV breasts and Tanner I pubic hair are suggestive of primary amenorrhea. The examination shows that the patient has Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, which is a congenital disorder that causes the vagina and uterus to be underdeveloped or absent. Gonadectomy (removal of the non-functioning testes or ovaries) is a common treatment for patients with this syndrome. Estrogen replacement therapy and vaginoplasty are also options, but gonadectomy is necessary to prevent malignant transformation of gonadal tissue. The ACTH stimulation test is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has primary amenorrhea, which suggests the absence of uterus, ovaries, or both. The blind pouch vagina also supports this diagnosis. Gonadectomy is the appropriate management for this patient. The other options are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has primary amenorrhea, breast development, and a blind vagina, which suggest Mullerian agenesis. A gonadectomy is recommended due to the risk of malignancy in patients with Y chromosome material. Estrogen replacement therapy and vaginoplasty may be considered later on, and an ACTH stimulation test is not relevant in this case.
